newsitem.title: USA: Attorneys argue money after Simpson verdict.
newsitem.headline: Attorneys argue money after Simpson verdict.

text.p: O.J. Simpson's wealth has dwindled from $8 million to $500,000 in the space of a year, according to records given to plaintiffs' attorneys by the defence in the former football star's civil trial.
Simpson's net worth is crucial following Tuesday's verdict which blamed Simpson for the June 12, 1994, murders of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald Goldman.

The jury, which granted the plaintiffs compensatory damages of $8.5 million, will hear testimony from financial experts on Thursday and must then decide on punitive damages to punish Simpson for his actions, which they found were performed with "malice" and "oppression."
According to an investigation by CNN and Time magazine published before Wednesday's court proceedings, Simpson's net worth was estimated at $11 million four years ago.

Plaintiffs' attorney Peter Gelblum told Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki in a hearing on Wednesday that when Simpson's attorneys first disclosed his finances they said he was worth $8 million, but in their latest papers he had only $500,000.
A source familiar with the case told Reuters the first financial disclosure was in February 1996.
A criminal court jury acquitted Simpson of the murders in October 1995. He was sued in the current wrongful death civil trial by the families of the victims.

Fujisaki, in the hearing on Wednesday with jurors absent, ruled the jury may be told by a plantiffs' expert that Simpson could earn more than $24 million over the next 20 years through endorsements and the sale of his "image and likeness."

The judge also rejected a motion by Simpson's lawyers that no punitive damages be awarded because members of the Brown and Goldman families and their attorneys breached the judge's "gag order" by talking to the press after the verdicts were read in court.

Simpson will serve no jail time, but could lose much of what is left of the fortune he earned in his days as a football star, advertising pitchman and sportscaster. Attorney Leo Terrell, a friend and strong supporter of Simpson, told Cable News Network the verdict would be appealed.
Attorney Robert Tourtelot, who filed suit on behalf of the Goldmans before being replaced, said the "huge" compensatory damages showed the punitive award "is going to be gigantic."
Legal analysts said the plaintiffs could hound him for the rest of his life, forcing him to auction his Bentley, give up his tennis courts and adopt a more modest lifestyle.
While only Goldman's family was entitled to compensatory damages, Nicole Brown Simpson's estate will share in any punitive award.

While the lawyers in the case were barred from comment on the trial, Harvard law professor Alan Dershowitz, an adviser to Simpson's criminal defence team, said there were "some very substantial issues" on which to base an appeal, including: "The admission of the lie-detector test evidence, the anonymous phone call to the battered women's hotline from a woman called Nicole."

Simpson testified he took a lie detector test as an experiment but disputed plaintiffs' attorney Daniel Petrocelli's assertion he failed it. A woman who told jurors she took the battered women's call from a "Nicole" said the caller complained she was being "stalked" by her ex-husband.

But Dershowitz held out little chance of a reversal of the verdict. "Judges in California are going to look very long and hard before they reverse what will be a very popular verdict among their constituents. I don't predict there will be a reversal of this verdict," he told NBC's "Today" show.

Christopher Darden, a member of the unsuccessful criminal trial prosecution team, said the difference in the civil case was that Simpson had to testify. "O.J. lied in front of this jury, he lied to the black community and he lied to the American public. This jury focused on the evidence, not race or politics," he said.
